entry.title: Episode 100215
entry.content:
Episode 100215

[Redacted Day] is 11 February, every year in memory of Aaron Swartz. Listen in as we discuss Windows 10 as a free update, the new Raspberry Pi 2 with twice the memory and four CPUs for the same money (£25) & running Win 10 and the rise of bots getting arrested (poker bot, art installation Darknet & robot vacuum cleaner eating hair).

Installed by shi on 2015-02-20

entry.title: Episode 140115
entry.content:
Episode 140115

Tune in as we bid farewell to David Carpenter, the founder of Bradford Linux Users Group, Aire Valley bike bus, and Record Club in Shipley, as he moves to greener pastures in Scotland. Listen as we waffle on about Facebook's "Year in Review" of lost loved ones, house fires and other assortment of calamities.

Installed by shi on 2015-01-25

entry.title: Episode 171214
entry.content:
Episode 171214

The last show of the year presents a plethora of tech stuff including the shenanigans of Sony Pictures, Consumerism in general, Stephen Hawking vs AI and the many adventures of Pirate Bay. Don't be fooled by the free viewing of, "The Interview" - Sony just wants you to forget about their epic fail!

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-12-31

entry.title: Episode 181114
entry.content:
Episode 181114

Plenty of reasons to celebrate this episode with several anniversaries - Windows is 29 years old, streaming radio on the web is 20 years old & Firefox is 10 years old - lots of lulz on Twitter starring Kim Cardassian, Bill Cosby, the Queen (yes, that one) & ill-timed tweets during the two minutes silence.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-11-28

entry.title: Episode 221014
entry.content:
Episode 221014

Coming up, we’ll be plugging a really important regular new event for young people here in Bradford - our very own CoderDojo, debriefing the recent evening at the Media Museum, another batch of interviews from the recent Leeds Hack event, Windows 10, the new Trolling law, the latest security scare - POODLE, celebrating women in computing on Ada Lovelace Day, #Gamergate, social networking news including Twitpic, Ello & Whisper, reminding everyone that Yahoo killed Geocities on the 26th October 2009 erasing internet history with one fell swoop before wrapping it all up with the very awesome, Grace Hopper.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-10-31

entry.title: Episode 230914
entry.content:
Episode 230914

Happy 40th birthday, Teletext! Join us in this momentous occassion as we natter about Minecraft's union with Microsoft, Fuji Xerox letting loose their robot/printer hybrid into the unsuspecting world, playing Doom on the control panel of the Canon Pixma, Twitter's evil ways, more Minecraft from the recent Leeds Hack 2014 report before ending on the upcoming "Let's Get Digital Lates" organised by the National Media Museum happening on Thursday, 9th October; 3 hours of pure adult fun with gaming as the focus. We'll be there in our Sunday best so hope to see you there!

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-10-03

entry.title: Episode 260814
entry.content:
Episode 260814

Today's show features cats, fish, gnomes, walruses and Brian! Sixty percent of that list was at the recent Leeds Hack event and we'll have special reports to prove it. We talk about the surprise buyout of Twitch.tv by Amazon where previously it was thought that Google was buying it.

Installed by shi on 2014-09-04

entry.title: Episode August 2014
entry.content:
Episode August 2014

Today's IT Stuff is jam packed with a flurry of local tech events for everyone featuring Leeds Hack at the Leeds City Museum on the 2nd - 3rd of August and Wuthering Bytes over at Hebden Bridge on the 15th - 17th August.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-07-30

entry.title: Episode July 2014
entry.content:
Episode July 2014

Dave & co is joined by our very own, homegrown Youtube megastar, the eponymous Dick of Dick’s Installs where we discuss the ethics behind Facebook's social experiment and why people are still using the service, Brazil's federal police password sharing initiative in l33t speak, why Eugene Goostman isn't the first bot to pass the elusive Turing Test and why this isn't as impressive as it's made out to be.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-07-08

entry.title: Episode June 2014
entry.content:
Episode June 2014

Dave & co reveal a Windows XP registry hack to get an extra five years worth of updates, reminding everyone about the ebay Password reset, wittle on about Youtube's notorious Content ID and their purchase of Twitch.tv, celebrate International Amiga Day with Swanky Art - a new kind of pixel art community, recite poetry about chromebooks and more Googly misdeamenours, including the right to be forgotten before ending on #LeedsArtCrawl, an Open Data game using twitter to crowdsource public art locations in Leeds.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-06-08

entry.title: Episode May 2014
entry.content:
Episode May 2014

Dave & co starts the show with Heartbleed bug repercussions (just 1.5 million casualties, no biggie), reminisce nostalgia to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of BASIC, announce the winners of the "Downtime of the month award" which seems to have an airport theme followed by a bit of browser news including Internet Explorer vulnerabilities (surprise!) and observations of the rather strange makeover of the latest Firefox browser, Firefox 29, making it look like another popular browser unlike itself before discussing the perils of social media and why some people just don't get it and to egregious effect.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-05-11

entry.title: Episode April 2014
entry.content:
Episode April 2014

Demonoid is back! This week introduces the OpenSSL ‘Heartbleed’ vulnerability, the 50th anniversary of the original Cobol 64 standard and the IBM 360, more website makeovers from Wikipedia, T&A and Flickr, The Internet of Things which apparently costs a total of £73M, disappointments shared over the Oculus Rift being bought by Facebook (for 2 billion big ones), why Blackcoin is better than Bitcoin followed by some good news about a notorious scam before we end the show with the past and future of Windows and Manchester’s Civic Space Programme.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-04-13

entry.title: Episode March 2014
entry.content:
Episode March 2014

Today's show reminds you to change your admin password if you have a Virgin Media Superhub2 router, talks about the Bitcoin meltdown as Mt Gox closes down, selfie news and much more silliness on the internet, specifically Twitter before touching on a more serious note about the British spooks at GCHQ intercepting and storing webcam images from 1.8 million Yahoo users worldwide.

The show ends on the demise of Windows XP followed by reports from the PiNest people at the University of Bradford.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-03-16

entry.title: Episode February 2014
entry.content:
Episode February 2014

Today's show talks about the Year of Code, the humourless antics of the Department of Work & Pensions and more government-related hullabaloo and the dangers of copycat sites, family filters that are doing none of us any good, spooks, spooks, spooks, the case of the missing Flappy Bird, support for the end of support for Windows XP and finally, inappropriate recommendations.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-02-15

entry.title: Episode January 2014
entry.content:
Episode January 2014

It's Anger Month! Today we talk about opting out of NHS data sharing and Google+ where anyone can email you directly, something Facebook users put up with as a default.

The government's new CyberStreetWise initiative including more money wasting activities on failing IT projects, spooks, spooks, spooks, Sky's brand new government approved smut filter, Snapchat ignoring a vulnerability warning that followed a hacking of their system, releasing 4.6 million user's details, Demonoid's tracker being back online before ending on the Gagging Bill and Youtube's Content ID malarkey. Bleurgh.

Read on
Installed by shi on 2014-01-18

entry.title: 21st November 2013
entry.content:
21st November 2013

The show includes:

Console Wars – discussion about the PS4, XBone, and Steam OS Passwords – big companies have been hacked again and passwords exposed. What do the IT Stuff presenters think about all this password nonesense?

News, including, YouTube, selfies, quantum computing, and does your laptop smell of cat wee – it may not be your cat’s fault.

If you have any feedback, we’d love to hear it.

Read on
Installed by David on 2013-11-21

27th June 2013

News about Bitcoin, Phones, Data Protection, and more. Goodbye to Google reader Launch of PS4 vs Xbox One Spookathon/Big Brother is watching – a discussion of recent revelations about privacy.

entry.title: 30th May 2013
entry.content:
30th May 2013

The show includes:

A discussion about the Communications Data Bill with a cameo from the Queen Live on air demo of the Oculus Rift, with assorted BradLUG member reactions.

Studio guests – Kriss, Shi and Dave C News, and general tech chatter, including the British Library’s UK Web Archive.

Worth tuning in for: The BradLUGers reactions to virtual reality The technical cock up in the middle (I don’t think anyone will notice)

If you have any feedback, we’d love to hear it.

Read on
Installed by David on 2013-05-30

entry.title: 2nd May 2013
entry.content:
2nd May 2013

The show includes:

An interview with Fab Lab (by Brian) Shi’s début behind the scenes ‘driving the desk’ Studio guests – John H and Kriss Book reviews, news, and general tech chatter.

It’s our first show that we have managed to create produce entirely on our own, so that’s a bit of a milestone, and credit to everyone that has put their time and effort in so far!

If you have any feedback, we’d love to hear it.

Read on
Installed by David on 2013-05-02
